What do you notice?
I notice that there is an upwards trend in temp after 1980. Before 1980 the number of high and low winter temperatures was relatively even compared to the 20th century average but after there are significantly more highs and significantly less lows. There was also a very extreme low temperature recorded in 1979 that was the lowest in the 20th century. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder how this data compares to data from other countries; does the trend vary across the world? I also wonder how this data changes across the U.S and how different areas are changing. In 1979 the U.S as a whole experienced a very low temperature and I wonder what (if anything) caused this low temperature and if it was predicted. I would also like to know how the data was recorded to know if it is reliable and what the average is. I wonder also how this data compared to the data from the polar vortex this winter and if the data predicted this or if it's unprecedented. Lastly, I would like to know how the temperatures of winters in the 20th century compare to the average temperature of the previous century because comparing them to the average of that century does not tell us much about how the temperatures changed in the 20th century 

What might be going on?
I think this graph shows how drastic the rate of climate change is in the 21st century. It shows how rapidly the winter temperatures in the US increased most likely due to change in lifestyle

name: Maggie M
comment info:

What’s going on in this graph?  A bar graph showing the temperature of the average winter by year from the 20th century on.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Maggie M --
You're not the only one that mentioned that this is a bar graph.  This certainly looks like a bar graph – after all, it has bars.  But, it isn’t a bar graph.  
Because the statistics are displayed on a 1900 – 2018 timeline, it is more like a time series graph.  But, not quite.  Time series graphs typically have points and not bars.  So, it’s not really a time series graph either.  
Though we learn in math class that there are specific graphs, like bar graphs, histograms, scatter plots, and time series, statisticians are designing new kinds of graphs all of the time.  Why?  Because they want to present the statistics in the way that most clearly displays the relationships of the statistics. 
How about sharing with us a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea?

name: Emily Rosenfeld
comment info:
1) I think it is a bar graph showing the differences between average winter temperatures measured by year. The temperatures in red could possibly be showing an increase in average temperatures and the blue temperatures could be showing a decrease in overall temperatures during exclusively the winter months. From my statistics class, I know we analyze a graphs shape, center, and spread. The shape of the red bars looks to be slightly skewed left and the blue bars look slightly skewed right., with one major outlier in the blue. The center (expected value) of the blue bars looks to be about -2 and the center of the red bars looks to be about 2. The red has a much higher spread and likely a higher standard deviation compared to the blues increased density and likely skewed standard deviation due to the single outlier near 1980.
2)I wonder what is the possible cause of the continuous increasing through recent years? 
3) Caption- American winter temperatures- are they getting warmer?

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Emily Rosenfeld --

Thank you for your in depth description of the graph and the headline.  

This certainly looks like a bar graph – after all, it has bars.  But, it isn’t a bar graph.  Because the statistics are displayed on a 1900 – 2018 timeline, it is more like a time series graph.  But, not quite.  Time series graphs typically have points and not bars.  So, it’s not really a time series graph either.  
Though we learn in math class that there are specific graphs, like bar graphs, histograms, scatter plots, and time series, statisticians are designing new kinds of graphs all of the time.  Why?  Because they want to present the statistics in the way that most clearly displays the relationships of the statistics. 

Tomorrow, look at The Reveal which is posted at the bottom of today's release.  One of the additional questions, explain how to take the statistics in this graph and make it into a histogram.  When you do this, you can describe the graph's center, shape, spread, and unusual data points.  Maybe you can share with us what you discover.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph:  "Doomsday Deviation" by Michael M, Harper C, Joseph P, and Owen M of Hampton High School, "Rising Into Warmer Waters" by Madison S of New Jersey,  and “You thought this Winter was cold? Check this graph" from Nathan of Virginia.



You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into this graph. Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, Jan. 24 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and the Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, JAN. 24, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, JAN. 30!  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to What's Going On In This Graph? 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who knows there has been less snow to shovel than when we were younger with the exception of 108 inches in 2015, and Kathy Dickensheets in Pittsburgh, who misses the big snowstorms, snow days, and sledding adventures that my family enjoyed so much when we were young.

name: Evan B
comment info:
We notice that as time goes on, the average winter temperature seems to increase overall, especially from 1980 onward. In the early 1900s on through the 1930s, there are large clusters of much cooler average temperatures, but it is the opposite from 1980 and on.
We think this because more CO2 emitted from factories and cars starting in the 1940s and China/India have since industrialized. There has been a lack in many CO2 regulations until recently.
We wonder: What caused the very cold winters of the early 1900s to 1930s? Why was there a large drop in average winter temperatures in the late 1970s? Why was there such a drastic turnaround from those much cooler temperatures to much warmer temperatures after that (which still continues today)?
We have learned from this graph that winters were once much colder on average than they are today, and there was a large drop in average winter temperatures in the late 1970s followed by a wave of a large increase in average winter temperatures, a wave we are still riding today.
Potential Headline: "Make Winters Cold Again"

name: Christian W.
comment info: We noticed in this graph that before the year 1940, most of the temperatures are lower than the 20th century average; consequently, after the year 1940, we see that most of the temperatures are higher than the 20th century average. We also noticed that the temperatures tend to increase over time, the opposite of this is true for the colder temperatures. The exception to this is around the year 1979 because the temperature in this year dropped lower than any other year shown in the graph - we wonder why this could be. We have learned that over time, the average winter temperature appears to increase. A potential headline for this graph could be "Heat Miser Strikes Again"

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi @Christian W. I love the headline you chose since it can be likened to the struggle between the hot and the cold in "The Year without a Santa Claus". However, there are no mystical creatures by the names of Heat Miser and Cold Miser battling it out for control of the world's temperature. Why do you think the heat is winning out even without the Heat Miser on its side? Are these the effects of naturally increasing temperatures, or the doing of man made emissions? Good observations on the trends, but does this progression of temperatures make sense to you?

name: Leroy, Josh, Zach, Bubba, and Brendan
comment info: I first noticed how the temperature around the most recent years has been increasing more and more. Other things that I have noticed are that the temperature dipped around the time of WW1, that there is a larger drop around 1980, and that usually, if there is a cold drop, the next year will be much warmer.  CO2 emissions continue to rise as seen in the above average temperature each year.  What we found interesting was  that 2016 was known to be one of the colder year's in Pittsburgh's history, but was the highest average.  Our title for this graph would be "Global Warming is a Heated Topic".

name: Madison S.
comment info: This graph shows the average winter temperatures by year compared to the 20th century average, shown as a basis line of 0. In this graph I notice that the years with an average winter temperature above the 20th century average are depicted in red, a warm color associated with heat. The color blue is used to represent the years in which the average is below the average. However, these lower averages include some purple values, and only a few truly blue values. This is organized in such a way to have people believe that even the colder years are not as frigid as they could be. All of this supports the trend of global warming. The graph shows the evolution of the climate to be warmer as a whole over the progression of time. I wonder how biased this graph is. Hopefully not much, as it was sourced from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Overall this graph can be used by people as proof of global warming, and a good headline for the graph would be, "Rising into Warmer Waters".

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Madison S.
Hello Madison.  Excellent work in checking for the source of the data and recognizing that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is likely to be a reliable source of information.  While this graph may not provide proof of global warming, it helps to support the concerns that exist for global warming and the need to further research climate change and the impact on our world of such changes.  Great headline too.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Madison S. Great points, girl. What is the long term effect we will suffer from "warmer waters"?

"Warmer Winters?"

comment info:
What I notice in this graph is that throughout the years, the average winter temperature has oscillated above and below the 20th century average, usually by roughly 3 degrees fahrenheit. In more recent years, however, the average winter temperature has been much higher than in the first half of the 20th century. The values that are lower than the mean are not as low as they were many years ago, but many values higher than the mean seem to be higher. This could be attributed to the various causes of global warming.
What I am wondering is what the value of the "20th century average" is and how much difference 5 degrees actually makes. I'm also wondering what might have happened in the late 70s that caused the outlier there.
One potential headline could be "Dreaming of a Green Christmas."

replies.name: I
replies.comment info: (As a side note, I feel the "various causes of global warming" could refer to not only emissions by motor vehicles, but also the likes of wildfires.)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Isaac
Hello Isaac.  Great wonderings and headline suggestion!

name: Carina P.
comment info: This graph shows the heavy variation of temperatures deviating from the average, both warmer and cooler, between the beginning of the 20th century through today, the different colors in the graph designating the more drastic changes in temperature.  On the topic of climate change, I think it is important to note how the graph's depiction of temperature is not about "warm" weather, but rather the inconsistencies and intense changes the climate has experienced- global warming doesn't mean the world is always getting warmer!

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Carina P.
Good afternoon Carina.  I appreciate your effort to use precise terminology.  You made great observations of the variation of deviations from the average temperature as well as your summary what global warming does not mean.

name: MiaF
comment info:
WOAH THIS GRAPH IS GREAT!!
It uses two of my favorite colors to depict how the yearly average temperature has wandered from the 20th-century average. It shows hints of global warming as the temperatures begin to rise above the 20th-century average after 1980. With smaller drops every couple years. I appreciate how the graph uses a WARM toned pink to show when the temperature was higher than the average and a COOL toned periwinkle to express lower temperatures. It is both clever and aesthetically pleasing. A concern of mine is that the title is "Climate at a Glance" and as a smart (if I do say so myself) high school senior it took me about 10 minutes to understand what I was looking at. I think that this graph could have been better portrayed.

name: Tina R

But as you move along the graph towards the later years there seems to be more spikes in higher temperatures. Showing the progression of changes in temperature throughout the 20th century.

name: Jeremy
comment info:
What do you notice? 
I noticed that some years it has been really cold and some years it has been hot compared to the average. I also noticed on how this graph only shows from 1900 to now. How come it doesn't show the years before 1900?

What do you wonder? 
I wonder how this data was collected, where it was collected, and how the 20th century average was found. I also wonder why the graph only included the contiguous US and not Alaska and Hawaii. Could it be that those states temperatures doesn't compare to the main idea that this graph is trying to push to the public?

What’s going on in this graph? 
The average temperature in each year is being compared to the 20th century average but what is interesting about this graph is on how there is no mention of what that 20th century average actually is. I don't know if it was just looked over or if someone is trying to hide something.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Jeremy
•	Good afternoon Jeremy.  Please look back tomorrow for the reveal of the original New York Times article where this graph and several others were first published to help answer your question about how the temperatures were collected.  You may also develop more questions after reading the article.  It is important to consider what the person who created the graph wants to emphasize.  It is also important to consider any potential bias when reading information or interpreting graphs in our world where we are bombarded with information, however this author is not trying to hide anything from us.  Think about how such temperatures were collected?  When and how might such collections have been made reliable?

name: Ben S.
comment info: From brief observations, I can conclude that this is a graph depicting the differences between the  average winter temperature in 1900 and the present average winter temperature at the time. Because of this, I'm curious if an increase in air pollution, carbon dioxide, and deforestation is responsible for the overall increase of winter temperatures on Earth. This graph could capture how pollution and an increase of carbon dioxide within the atmosphere  because the gas prevents small bits of heat from the sun from escaping the Earth's atmosphere, forcing it to bounce back to the Earth's surface as more thermal energy from the sun reaches our planet. A similar phenomenon has been present on Venus, which, due to the gases within Venus' atmosphere capturing the majority of thermal energy from the sun, has made Venus the hottest planet in the Solar System.

We learned that:
Global warming is a real thing.

The Great Freeze of 1980

name: Justin
comment info:
While looking through the graph, I noticed that there seemed to be larger increases in temperature as well as  more temperatures above the 20th century average as time continued to pass. However, there did seem to be some extraneous years that went against the trends as shown around the 1980s with one year having the lowest point overall at –5 degrees under the global average. There also seemed to be changes in color depending on the how far the temperature was from the global average. 

 

For the most part, there isn't much that I wonder too much about, but I'm curious as to what events could have caused some of the more unexpected shifts in temperature that can account for some of the unexpected dips. I'm also curious about what the 20th century average was in terms of temperature for the graph just for more clarification on how problematic or problematic the situation is. 

 

Most likely, the graph was related to the idea that temperatures began to warm as time has gone on and by using the colors, the closer to red it becomes, the warmer the temperature, and the more blue it becomes, the colder the temperature with a majority of temperatures above the 20th century average occurring near the end. I'm not good at names at all so the best I can do for a headline is "Trends Show an Increase in the Global Temperature", which says what I think the main idea, but could probably be better.

The purpose of this graph is probably to illustrate the issues that the world has been having with climate change, which is a relatively recent issue that came about with new technologies in the modern world.  This graph accurately depicts this issue and generates concern because it highlights the extremes in highs and lows over short time spans, such as the extreme span from about 1934-1936.

name: Tejas
comment info:
I noticed that there seems to be a weak positive correlation between the number of years after 1900 and the difference between the average winter temperature of that year and the 20th century winter temperature average. This statement can be backed up by the fact that there are more cases of the average winter temperature being below the 20th century average in the first 2/3s of the time frame and more cases of the average winter temperature being above the 20th century average in the lat parts of the time frame.

I wonder why there was such a strong outlier around the year 1979. After further research it appears that this strong outlier was the "Brutal Winter of 1978-1979". However, we also wondered why the somewhat strong outlier at 1936 was not as intensive as we thought, since according to our research, it contained many records for the coldest temperatures experienced within the United States. Additionally, I wonder how frequently the temperatures were recorded for each year in order to calculate the average. Was it every day? At what specific hour was the reading taken, and could taking a temperature at a different hour while using the same data calculation, would it result in a different trend? 

The story this graph tells is the trend of average winter temperatures since about 1900, specifically on how it is seeming to, over time, more consistently lie above the 20th century winter average.

A cool headline for this graph could be "Fire and Ice... then Fire again!"

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:

name: Kero K and Jon I
comment info:
1- We notice that around the year 1990 and after, the average winter temperatures for each year appear to be, on average, above the 20th century average. This appears to be different than the story the data shows before 1990.
2- We think that the data from before ~1990 and after 1990 tell two different stories, with a possible c
3- We wonder if the technological advances made since the early 1990s impacted how the data was collected. Since the increments on the y-axis are only one degree apart with lots of spacing, any variance in the collection of data could potentially be amplified in how the data is displayed on the graph. We would like to research the accuracy of the weather measuring tools used earlier in the 20th century to ensure the validity of the earlier readings. If the readings are "off," this would likely impact the 20th century average line.

name: Mia D.
comment info: This graph illustrates the changes in temperature over the years in comparison to the 20th century average temperature. The tracking of temperatures starts in the year 1900 and goes all the way up to present temperatures in 2018. The first thing I noticed was the color choices. The creators of this graph strategically represented years in which the temperature was lower than the national average with a blue bar, and in contrast, the years that were warmer than the national average red. My eye was immediately drawn to the extreme highs and lows. For example, in 1978-79, the average temperature for the year was about 6 degrees lower than the 20th century average. In around 2016, the temperature was about 4.5 degrees higher than the 20th century average. By analyzing these observations, one can come to the conclusion that though there have been years in which the temperature dropped, temperatures have increased overall through the years of the 20th century. I wonder if this graph can help scientists make any predictions about global warming...

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Andrew --
Scientists define extreme changes in average temperature as more than 3 degrees in either direction.  How frequently are there extreme temperatures?  Has this percentage changed over the 118 years of data?
You also ask, “Where this information was collected?”  GOOD question.  And, how was it collected.  Go to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration website to learn more.

I wonder what the new average is and if it might stay the same because the first half is very cold and the second half is very warm.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Nathaniel --
Your last wondering about recalculating the average temperature by including more recent temperatures is similar to calculating a moving or trailing average.  This statistic changes the input data to the most recent data, for example, the past ten years, and recalculates the average for each year.  
What would a graph of the moving average look like for this data?  Decreasing, increasing or staying constant over time?

name: Maxim
comment info: Hottest Winter's in Years! I notice that it is possible that because of the smoke generated in the air in the 1900's, extra sunlight was blocked out, which  generated cooler temperatures. I am curious as to why we have hotter winters by a significant amount on alternating years from the 1900's and what the summers are like; do they reflect similar patterns?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Maxim --
You mention “a significant amount on alternating years from the 1900's.”  What’s the cause of this alternating?  Or, could it be random – just happened by chance?  
A way to test if the alternating is random is to compare the percentage of times the change alternated over the 118 years and compare this to a random simulation.  This is what you could do. 
Calculate the average of the sum of rolling two dice.  Then, roll two dice many times and see how frequently the sums alternate greater or less than the average.  Is this about what the graph shows or different?  If it is comparable (about the same), then maybe the alternating of temperatures is just random.  If not, then maybe there is another reason why this happens.  
If you do this experiment, share with us what you discover.
Also, to learn about how summer temperatures have changed, you can look in the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” archives.  The May 8, 2018 graph is entitled “It’s Not Your Imagination. Summers Are Getting Hotter.”  Take a look to see the graph, its article, and the student responses.

name: nathan
comment info:

The graph is showing how far above or below average temperature each year's winter was.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @nathan --
Using your noticings, please share with us a catchy headline what captures the graph’s main ideas.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s graph compares the winter temperature for the years 1900 – 2018 to the average winter temperature for the 20th century. From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  
Plus, share with us a catchy headline that captures your ideas about the graph. 
On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
(The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow, Thursday, Jan. 24 with moderation on Wednesday, January 30.)

name: Justin
comment info:
There are bar graphs going in the positive and negative directions 

I wonder what the bar graphs represent 

Each data point represents the difference (whether positive or negative) between the average temperature vs the temperature in a specific year in the 20th century

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Justin --
This certainly looks like a bar graph – after all, it has bars.  But, it isn’t a bar graph.  Because the statistics are displayed on a 1900 – 2018 timeline, it is more like a time series graph.  But, not quite.  Time series graphs typically have points and not bars.  So, it’s not really a time series graph either.  
Though we learn in math class that there are specific graphs, like bar graphs, histograms, scatter plots, and time series, statisticians are designing new kinds of graphs all of the time.  Why?  Because they want to present the statistics in the way that most clearly displays the relationships of the statistics.
